results.title: The Blinds and the Shutters
results.brief_description: This work presents a virtual world comprised of a modernist fictional house in a remote forest setting, whose contents gradually spill and float out of every aperture. Shoes and dresses, pots and pans, cutlery, pillows, blankets and plates journey in two directions simultaneously, some disappearing into the distance never to return, others appearing across all four screens in the installation. The larger objects fade up like apparitions, disappear and then reappear in strange locations, breaking all logic that is guiding this imaginary world. The slow drift of these household objects around the four screens is uncanny. While their journey suggests that the natural phenomenon of air is present, there is also a sense of airlessness; a claustrophobic, almost heavily scented environment. Despite sharing an energy force within the virtual environment, these objects are estranged – for they have lost their domestic relationship with one another. The sounds of bumps, collisions and muffled shuffles emerging from the interior of the house underscores the mystery of this scene. The disturbing atmosphere is most bizarre when the household goods are propelled into outer space, taking on the form of miniature satellites presumably tracking our behaviour from afar.

results.title: The Blind Man of Siloam
results.brief_description: The Salvation Army isn’t just part of Melbourne’s social fabric, it’s also an integral part of moving image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department, from 1897 to 1910. Here they produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors with elaborate sets and costumes, printing them on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique recreated ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns as well as hymns, music, motion picture segments and rousing narration.

results.title: The Blessed event: quandary
results.brief_description: A married woman is upset when she discovers she is pregnant. She has just returned to work and doesn’t want a second child. Her quandary is about telling her husband, who is against abortion. This program will be of interest to a wide range of people, as well as educators, counsellors, community health and women’s organisations and marriage counselling services.

results.title: The Blair Witch Project
results.creator_credit: Haxan Films, Greg Hale, Robin Cowie, Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez
results.brief_description: Presented as a documentary “The Blair Witch Project” tells of a group of students lost in the woods in search of the world of witchcraft. The story is told using the found documentary footage of the group recovered from the forest. Successfully creepy this low budget feature with jerky camerawork is understatedly disturbing.

results.title: The Blainey view: the great depression
results.creator_credit: David Goldie, ABC-TV (Australia) and Ashley Smith
results.brief_description: Narrated by Graham Kennedy and presented by Geoffrey Blainey, this 30 minute presentation looks at the effect the 1929 stock market crash had on Australians as Australia was plunged into economic depression in the 1930’s. The burden was not shared equally amongst all Australians either, with the unemployed and self employed hit hardest. Those who lived throughout the era reflect on the poverty as well as a sense of comraderie and community developed through adversity. Geoffrey Blainey questions what could have been done to overcome the unemployment then, as well as the lessons that can be applied to unemployment today.

results.title: The Blade
results.brief_description: Visually innovative and brutal in its action sequences, “The Blade” is essentially a traditional tale of revenge, rivalry and romance. In the town of Empire Field, a desolate waste-land laden with booby traps and populated by gangs of bandits, lies the best sword making factory in the country - Sharp Manufacturers. Introduced from the point of view of Ling, the master sword maker’s daughter, she contemplates her place in such a world and dreams of workers Iron Head (Moses Chan) and On (Chiu Man-Cheuk) vying for her affections. When her father hands over the industry to On, he discovers his father was killed by the tattooed bandit, Lung, and vows to avenge the father he never knew. Ling, not willing to let On go follows after him with Iron Head. Overtly concerned with halves and incompleteness, On’s father leaves the legacy of half a sword, On is injured in a fight with bandits and loses an arm, and when he finds the manual that will teach him the necessary intricacies of being a master swordsman capable of taking on Tung, half the manual is missing. On’s incompleteness adds fuel to his fire of revenge to right the wrongs of the dispossessed in a society where only the strong prevail and On rises to become the One Armed Swordsman. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: The Blacksmith
results.creator_credit: Buster Keaton Films, Raymond Rohauer, Joseph Schenck, Buster Keaton and Malcolm St Clair
results.brief_description: Buster Keaton as a hapless blacksmith muddles his way through various comic situations in inimitable Keaton style. New shoes for a lady’s horse, a revolutionary saddle for another lady rider, repairs to a young fop’s expensive car and an encounter with a bratty child, lead to inevitable mayhem but with Buster emerging triumphant in the end. Cast also includes Joe Roberts and Virginia Fox.

results.title: The Blackbutt
results.brief_description: The Blackbutt, a majestic gum is felled. The removal of the tree was necessary as a fence nailed to it allowed termites to enter, nest and rot the tree with their activities. The gum is shown in all its beauty; then the preparations for its removal - dismantling the fence and the electricity wires; digging to expose the roots; lopping the branches; cutting the roots. The final act of felling comes as the winch tightens the steel ropes. The termite nest is found in the base and their activities seen in the rotten, gnarled branches. There is no commentary, but specially selected music augments the visual impressions. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: The Blackbird = La Merle (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Norman McLaren imparts unusual activity to an old French-Canadian nonsense song. Simple white cut-outs on pastel backgrounds provide lively illustrations. The folksong, (Mon Merle), is sung in French by the Trio Lyrique of Montreal. This, the only white blackbird in creation, is a wonderful amalgam of Buster Keaton, Marcel Marceau and McLaren.
